de.lmu.ifi.dbs.elki.database.ids

Interface DBIDIter

  • All Superinterfaces:
    DBIDRef, Iter
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    DBIDArrayIter, DBIDArrayMIter, DBIDMIter, DistanceDBIDResultIter<D>, DoubleDistanceDBIDResultIter, IntegerDBIDArrayIter, IntegerDBIDArrayMIter, IntegerDBIDIter, IntegerDBIDMIter
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    DBIDIterAdapter, DoubleDistanceDBIDList.Iter, DoubleDistanceKNNList.Itr, EmptyDBIDs.EmptyDBIDIterator, GenericDistanceDBIDList.Iter, GenericKNNList.Itr, IntArrayStaticDBIDs.DBIDItr, IntegerDBID.DBIDItr, IntegerDBIDRange.DBIDItr, IntegerDBIDVar.DBIDItr, KNNUtil.KNNSubList.Itr, MaskedDBIDs.DBIDItr, MaskedDBIDs.InvDBIDItr, TroveArrayDBIDs.DBIDItr, TroveHashSetModifiableDBIDs.DBIDItr, UnmodifiableArrayDBIDs.UnmodifiableDBIDArrayIter, UnmodifiableDBIDs.UnmodifiableDBIDIter, UnmodifiableIntegerArrayDBIDs.UnmodifiableDBIDIter, UnmodifiableIntegerDBIDs.UnmodifiableDBIDIter

    public interface DBIDIter
extends DBIDRef, Iter
    Iterator for DBIDs. Important note: this iterator has a significantly different syntax and semantics than the Java iterators. It is much more aligned with C than with Java, but at the same time, the syntax is much more compatible with for loops. Usage example: 
     for (DBIDIter iter = ids.iter(); iter.valid(); iter.advance()) {
   Object o = relation.get(iter); // Many interfaces allow direct use
   DBID id = DBIDUtil.deref(iter); // Materialize only if you need to!
 }
    We list some fundamental differences.
    • iter.valid() refers to the current element, Iterator.next() to the next.
    • iter.advance() does not return an element. Use get... to access it.
    • DBIDIter.get... do not advance the iterator.

    • Method Summary

      • Methods inherited from interface de.lmu.ifi.dbs.elki.database.ids.DBIDRef

        equals, hashCode, internalGetIndex

      • Methods inherited from interface de.lmu.ifi.dbs.elki.utilities.iterator.Iter
